Dear Ms. Prudhomme:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
June 5, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed or
implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Shay Mavis at (269) 243-2725.
Sincerely,
Barbara A Cote, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
• (1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:

• (j) A written evaluation of the employee's
performance within 30 days of the
completion of the probationary period or
within 180 days, whichever is less, and a
written evaluation of the employee's
performance annually thereafter.
Two of nine employee files contained late performance evaluations. One was
three days late and one was five days late.

The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The facility was offered consultation to create a more detailed assistant supervisor
job description, separate from the supervisor job description.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
2024 Renewal: Corrective Action Plan was recorded during this reporting period
as a result of the Renewal inspection completed on 4/30/2024. This CAP
contained two rule violations of CCI Rule 400.4113 regarding employee records.
There was one employee file that did not have a written evaluation addressing a
conviction and the facility failed to provide a statement addressing the conviction.
The CAP contained action steps to ensure a checklist was created and followed
when hiring individuals.
Special investigation 2024SIC0001250 with CAP approval date of 6/27/2024 was
a result of an incident report not being completed within the required timeframe
and the facility being out of ratio. The facility created a new procedure to log, track
and review incidents to ensure they are entered on time and changed their
3

contract to a 2:1 ratio. The agency is currently complying with the CAP action
steps and DCWL continues to monitor CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
Special Investigation 2025SIC0000229 with CAP approval date of 3/20/2025 was
a result of staff not following the Behavior Support and Management Policy and
failing to notify the proper parties for a youth who went AWOL. The facility
reviewed the Behavior Support and Management Policy during Academy and
created a Professional Development Plan with the staff member. The AWOL and
Out of Bounds procedures were changed and reviewed with all staff during
Academy. The agency is currently complying with the CAP action steps, and
DCWL continues to monitor CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
Special Investigation 2025SIC0000553 with a pending CAP was a result of a staff
member not following the Code of Conduct Policy and locking/securing her
nicotine vape. The facility is working to complete the CAP.
Special Investigation 2025SIC0000569 with a pending CAP was a result of the
facility misplacing a grievance filed by a youth and therefore not addressing the
grievance. The facility is working to complete the CAP.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on a review of the annual financial
audit report.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator reported the youth in Ashmun and Sherk have been stable
and doing well. There have been minimal issues and staffing within those houses
has been consistent.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff denied any concerns with youth not receiving the services needed and
required for them to be successful in the program. Staff reported youth are offered
numerous community activities and outings to participate in. Staff stated there is
weekly training where policies are reviewed and updates provided to staff.
Youth reported in interviews feeling safe and having at least one staff to talk with
when having issues. One youth stated how she enjoys having a mentor at the
facility and getting one on one time with that individual. Youth stated their needs
are being met.
4

Description of Agency Walk Through
An on-site inspection and walkthrough of both houses occurred on May 21, 2025.
There were no issues or safety concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
